title: [BUG] Incorrect tag: `ignores-exogeneous-X` for Reduced Regression Models?
body:
**Describe the bug**
The tags for Reduced Regression models seem to indicate that they do not support exogenous variables. But when I run the snippet of code below, I clearly see the difference in results based on whether exogenous variables are passed or not. 

Does the tag reflect the correct behavior?

**To Reproduce**
```python
from sktime.datasets import load_longley
from sktime.forecasting.compose import TransformedTargetForecaster, make_reduction
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression

y, X = load_longley()
fh=[1, 2, 3, 4]

forecaster = make_reduction(estimator=LinearRegression(), scitype="tabular-regressor", window_length=12, strategy="recursive")
print(forecaster)
print(f"Ignores X: {forecaster.get_tag('ignores-exogeneous-X')}\n\n")

#### With Exogenous ----
forecaster.fit(y, X, fh=fh)
preds = forecaster.predict(X=X[-4:])
print(f"Predictions with Exogenous:\n {preds}\n")

#### Without Exogenous ----
forecaster = make_reduction(estimator=LinearRegression(), scitype="tabular-regressor", window_length=12, strategy="recursive")
forecaster.fit(y, fh=fh)
preds = forecaster.predict()
print(f"Predictions without Exogenous:\n {preds}\n")
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33585645/158032777-1325e773-6152-45d5-b3a8-f7983a33d4db.png)



**Expected behavior**
I would have expected the model to utilize exogenous variables appropriately as it is nothing but a regression model. So the behavior seems to be ok, but the tag seems to be incorrect.
